instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
This 12" Macbook was sent in as intermittently turning on when the charger gets plugged in. I removed the USB-C charging port and noticed one of the pins were gone so I replaced the port and it turned on fine after that. The only issue was that the keyboard and trackpad were not working so I replaced the trackpad cable and everything worked fine after that. I was able to shut down the machine and turn it on multiple times with no problems.

The last thing I did was run the apple diagnostics test and after it passed I shut it down and left the charger in for another 30 minutes before unplugging it. This morning I tried turning it on and it won't turn on with the charger plugged in and even after an SMC reset.

Here are some measurements I got. The 5v and 3v3 s5 rails are present but the s4 rails and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is not present.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL> - 20v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> - 3.24v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.29v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5v

I tried measuring <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> but as far as I can tell it is at 0v. It was kind of hard to get correct spots to measure it because the probe points and resistors didn't look to be in the exact spot as the boardview says.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message: There’s probably corrosion somewhere on the board or under a chip.I’d say ultrasonic and go from there if the history is liquid damage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
The customer said there was never any liquid spilled on it. It was just an issue with the charger port but I will ultrasonic it and see if that fixes it.

Update: I ultrasonic'd the board but still have the same issue. I know the board is getting power because the white led comes on when the charger is plugged in without the battery being connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
Disconnect keyboard and see if board starts when plug in the charger.
You can also simulate power button using <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads.
Check for any reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> when you do that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
Yes I've been doing all of these tests with only the board and usb port plugged in(no other accessories plugged in).

I don't even get a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> when I plug in the charger and when I use the <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
Check PCH's RTC signals.
Also check for 32KHz at pin9/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
I wasn't sure what rtc signals to check so I searched rtc in the boardview and took these measurements.
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 1.52v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.28v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.29v
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> - 1.08v

Pin 1(<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>) of <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> is 3.28v but Pin 2(<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL>) shows 1.52v so I think that may be a problem. It measured 20kohms so the resistor seems fine.

I have a fluke 115 multimeter but I'm not sure how to measure khz on a chip. Is it possible to measure that with this multimeter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 1.55v"
There resides your problem...
Check <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> value.
If correct, remove <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR>; if voltage goes high to 3V, change <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR>.
If still low value, bad PCH; END.

BTW, the other two RTC signals are INTRUDER and INTVRMEN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message:
I removed <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR> and it went to 3v so that was the problem. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR> and everything is working fine now. 

Thanks a lot!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> s4 rails not present
threads.message: Good job! Screenshotting this for future reference in case something similar comes my way
